Title:
Cordyceps mexicanum sp. nov., parasitizing Paradirphia sp.
moths; a new sister species of the Cordyceps militaris complex,
distributed in Central Mexican Quercus-Pinus mixed forests
Keywords:
KEY WORDS: Cordycipitaceae, diversity, Lepidoptera, life
cycle.
Abstract:
ABSTRACT: Cordyceps s.l. is a paraphyletic group of
ascomycete fungi that exhibit multifunctional lifestyles as saprotrophs,
endophytes and pathogens of insects, spiders, fungi, and grasses.
Cordycipitaceae includes macroscopically similar species that have been
erroneously considered conspecific with C. militaris. In this study,
based on morphology, phylogenetic relationships, and life cycle, we
describe a new species within the Cordyceps militaris complex that is
distributed in the Quercus-Pinus forests of central Mexico. Cordyceps
mexicanum, sp. nov. parasitizes pupae of Paradirphia sp. Lepidoptera:
Saturniidae: Hemileucinae. This species can be confused macroscopically
with C. militaris, Blackwellomyces cardinalis and B. pseudomilitaris.
Phylogenetically, Cordyceps mexicanum is a well-supported new species,
sister to Cordyceps militaris complex. It is distinguished by its
conidiophore morphology, host association and geographic distribution.
Its stromata are bright yellow, contrasting with those of C. militaris,
which are yellow, orange or reddish. Microscopically, it develops asci
with disarticulating filiform ascospores in part-spores, as in C.
militaris; however, in contrast to B. cardinalis and B. pseudomilitaris,
which present asci with non-disarticulating ascospores. The perithecia,
asci, and ascospores are larger than those of C. oncoperae, C. rosea, C.
kyusyuensis, C. militaris, C. submilitaris and C. kirkii. Its life
cycle, horizontal transmission and geographical distribution are
discussed.
